title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
plot_summary: Set in the early 19th century, 'Pride and Prejudice' follows the character of Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates issues of manners, upbringing, morality, education, and marriage in the society of the landed gentry of the British Regency. Elizabeth is the second of five daughters of a country gentleman living near the fictional town of Meryton in Hertfordshire, near London. Throughout the novel, Elizabeth and her family interact with various other characters, including the handsome and wealthy bachelor Mr. Fitzwilliam Darcy, with whom Elizabeth develops a relationship marked by misunderstandings and mutual antipathy.

author: George Orwell
plot_summary: '1984' is set in a dystopian future where the world has fallen into perpetual war, omnipresent government surveillance, and propaganda. The story unfolds in the superstate of Oceania, under the watchful eye of the Party and its leader, Big Brother. Winston Smith, the protagonist, works for the Ministry of Truth, where he alters historical records to fit the Party's propaganda. His growing disillusionment with the Party and his illicit love affair with Julia lead him on a path of rebellion and a quest for truth, only to face the grim realities of the regime.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
plot_summary: The novel is set in the 1930s in a small Alabama town and is narrated by 6-year-old Jean Louise 'Scout' Finch. Her father, Atticus Finch, is a lawyer who is defending a black man, Tom Robinson, accused of raping a white woman. Through Scout’s eyes, the novel explores the themes of racial injustice and the destruction of innocence. Atticus, as one of the few residents who believes in racial equality, becomes a moral hero for Scout and her brother, Jem, as they navigate a world of prejudice and harsh realities.

title: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
plot_summary: Set in the Jazz Age on Long Island, the novel depicts narrator Nick Carraway's interactions with mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby and Gatsby's obsession to reunite with his former lover, Daisy Buchanan. The story is a critique of the American Dream, as Gatsby's dream of Daisy is corrupted by wealth and dishonesty, reflecting the hedonistic society of the time. The novel explores themes of decadence, idealism, resistance to change, and excess, culminating in tragedy.

title: Moby Dick
author: Herman Melville
plot_summary: 'Moby Dick' is a complex narrative that explores the adventures of the monomaniacal quest of Ahab, captain of the whaling ship Pequod, for revenge on Moby Dick, the giant white sperm whale that on the ship's previous voyage bit off Ahab's leg at the knee. The novel is a mix of adventure narrative, sermon, and philosophical treatise, with a detailed and realistic depiction of the whaling industry and seafaring life.

title: Jane Eyre
author: Charlotte Brontë
plot_summary: The novel follows the emotions and experiences of its eponymous heroine, including her growth to adulthood and her love for Mr. Rochester, the brooding master of Thornfield Hall. The narrative traverses Jane's childhood as an orphan, her education at Lowood School, her time as the governess of Thornfield Hall, her moral and spiritual development, and the emotional obstacles she faces.

title: Animal Farm
author: George Orwell
plot_summary: This allegorical novella reflects events leading up to and during the Stalin era before World War II. 'Animal Farm' tells the story of a group of farm animals who rebel against their human farmer, hoping to create a society where the animals can be equal, free, and happy. Ultimately, however, the rebellion is betrayed, and the farm ends up in a state as bad as it was before, under the dictatorship of a pig named Napoleon.

title: Wuthering Heights
author: Emily Brontë
plot_summary: The narrative is non-linear, revolving around the intense and tragic story of Catherine Earnshaw and Heathcliff, an orphan brought to live at Wuthering Heights by Catherine's father. The story involves themes of passion, revenge, and the supernatural, spanning two generations. Heathcliff's destructive force is countered by the enduring love he holds for Catherine, which leads to his eventual downfall.

title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
author: Mark Twain
plot_summary: This novel is about the adventures of a young boy, Huck, and a runaway slave, Jim, as they travel down the Mississippi River on a raft. Throughout their journey, they encounter various characters and situations that satirize the Antebellum South, slavery, and Southern antebellum society. The novel is noted for its colorful description of people and places along the Mississippi River and its sober, often critical look at entrenched attitudes, particularly racism.

title: Frankenstein
author: Mary Shelley
plot_summary: This novel tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a sapient creature in an unorthodox scientific experiment. Shelley started writing the story when she was 18, and the first edition was published anonymously in London on 1 January 1818, when she was 20. Her name first appeared on the second edition, published in 1823. Frankenstein is infused with elements of the Gothic novel and the Romantic movement and is also considered to be one of the earliest examples of science fiction.

title: White Fang
author: Jack London
plot_summary: Set in the Yukon during the 1890s Klondike Gold Rush, 'White Fang' details the wild life of a wolf-dog named White Fang. The novel explores themes of morality, redemption, and the harsh realities of nature. It portrays White Fang's journey from wildness to becoming domesticated by humans, particularly by Weedon Scott, who treats him with kindness and respect.

title: The Call of the Wild
author: Jack London
plot_summary: This novel tells the story of a dog named Buck who is stolen from his home and sold into the brutal existence of an Alaskan sled dog. He progressively reverts to a wild state in the harsh Arctic environment. The novel explores themes of survival and the clash between civilization and the natural world.

title: Mrs. Dalloway
author: Virginia Woolf
plot_summary: 'Mrs. Dalloway' chronicles a day in the life of Clarissa Dalloway, a high-society woman in post–World War I England. It covers her preparations for a party she will host that evening and includes the backstories of several characters she encounters. The novel addresses the internal thoughts and philosophies of its characters, exploring themes of mental illness, existentialism, and feminism.

title: To the Lighthouse
author: Virginia Woolf
plot_summary: The novel is centered around the Ramsay family and their visits to the Isle of Skye in Scotland between 1910 and 1920. It explores the family's dynamics and the passage of time, and is particularly focused on the characters' internal reflections. The central part of the novel is a meditation on the passage of time and the changes it brings to individuals and relationships.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
plot_summary: This novel focuses on the mental anguish and moral dilemmas of Rodion Raskolnikov, an impoverished ex-student in Saint Petersburg who formulates a plan to kill an unscrupulous pawnbroker for her money. The novel delves into the psychology of crime and punishment, and explores themes of guilt, redemption, and the nature of evil.

title: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
plot_summary: Narrated by a young man named Holden Caulfield, this novel details his life in New York City after being expelled from prep school. The narrative follows Holden's experiences and interactions over a few days, exploring themes of adolescent angst, alienation, and the loss of innocence.

title: Brave New World
author: Aldous Huxley
plot_summary: Set in a futuristic World State, inhabited by genetically modified citizens and an intelligence-based social hierarchy, the novel anticipates huge scientific advancements in reproductive technology, sleep-learning, psychological manipulation, and classical conditioning. The story questions the loss of individuality in the pursuit of technological progress.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
author: John Steinbeck
plot_summary: This novel tells the story of the Joads, a poor family of tenant farmers driven from their Oklahoma home by drought, economic hardship, and changes in the agriculture industry. In a journey filled with hardship, they travel to California, suffering the misfortunes of the homeless in the Great Depression.

title: A Tale of Two Cities
author: Charles Dickens
plot_summary: Set in London and Paris before and during the French Revolution, the novel tells the story of the French Doctor Manette, his 18-year-long imprisonment in the Bastille in Paris, and his release to live in London with his daughter Lucie, whom he had never met. The story is set against the conditions that led up to the French Revolution and the Reign of Terror.

title: Heart of Darkness
author: Joseph Conrad
plot_summary: This novella details Charles Marlow's journey up the Congo River as a ferry-boat captain. He is tasked with retrieving Mr. Kurtz, a renowned ivory trader, who has gone missing in the African jungle. The narrative explores themes of imperialism, colonialism, and the darkness that lies in the human heart.
